body: The amount of religious people who truly hate gay people is likely a lot lower than you think. Disapproval of someone's lifestyle because it goes against personal convictions is a lot different than hatred. body:
Matthew 28:19 

19 Go, therefore, make disciples of all nations; baptise them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,

2 Corinthians 13:13 

13 The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all.

1 Corinthians 12:4-5    

4 There are many different gifts, but it is always the same Spirit; 

5 there are many different ways of serving, but it is always the same Lord.

Ephesians 4:4-6

4 There is one Body, one Spirit, just as one hope is the goal of your calling by God.

5 There is one Lord, one faith, one baptism,

6 and one God and Father of all, over all, through all and within all.

1 Peter 1:2

2 in the foresight of God the Father, to be made holy by the Spirit, obedient to Jesus Christ and sprinkled with his blood: Grace and peace be yours in abundance.

Revelation 1:4-5

4 John, to the seven churches of Asia: grace and peace to you from him who is, who was, and who is to come, from the seven spirits who are before his throne,

5 and from Jesus Christ, the faithful witness, the First-born from the dead, the highest of earthly kings. He loves us and has washed away our sins with his blood,


Source: https://www.catholic.org/bible/

parent.body: I don't believe that Jesus explicitly said to worship him as God or part of a trinity.
parent.body_html: I don't believe that Jesus explicitly said to worship him as God or part of a trinity.

body:
No. I don't understand why you hold the Bible infallible or at the very least relatively unscathed by the passage of time. For example, Paul/Saul says in a dream that Jesus told him that all foods are permissible. Why do you take the word of Saul over the old testament?

I take so much of the Bible very lightly because I don't know who are the authors or conveyers.

However in Islam, we have an unbroken 1400 year old undisputed chain of transmission of the Book (the Quran), and a plethora of the sayings (the hadith). I can peruse volumes on the authenticity of different quotes of Muhammad (sallahu alayhi wasalam), let alone the translation of a verse of the Book. For this reason I have a general trust in the literature and scholarship. Not only do I know the conveyer of the Book (the tongue of the Prophet sallahu alayhi salam), but also the context in which it was given to him by God. The corpus is more than expansive and often self-scrutinizing.

However, when I read the Gospels growing up (I was raised Catholic), I found that one does not even know who is the author that is conveying to me the Bible. This didn't make me disbelieve in God or the nobility and status of Jesus or his miracles by the permission of God, but rather it made me take each verse with a grain of salt.

My question is, how do you trust that these Bible verses are the actual teachings of Jesus (alayhi salam)? 

I fear that a significant portion of the Bible is the writings of man and not revelation - instruction (found most untouched in the Gospels). How do you verify what is in the Bible?

And my previous comment. I don't believe that he **explicitly** says to worship a trinity. All of the verses you listed could only lead to belief in a three-in-one clover God in a round about fashion (and it did indeed take nearly 300 years to be the de-facto Christian teaching).

This didn't make me disbelieve in God or the nobility and status of Jesus or his miracles by the permission of God, but rather it made me take each verse with a grain of salt.

My question is, how do you trust that these Bible verses are the actual teachings of Jesus (alayhi salam)?

I fear that a significant portion of the Bible is the writings of man and not revelation - instruction (found most untouched in the Gospels). How do you verify what is in the Bible?

And my previous comment. I don't believe that he explicitly says to worship a trinity. All of the verses you listed could only lead to belief in a three-in-one clover God in a round about fashion (and it did indeed take nearly 300 years to be the de-facto Christian teaching).

body:
>Jesus is either God or a liar

Or the people that conveyed that Jesus said he is God incarnate are mistaken (the Islamic stance for hundreds of years). We would not like to call them liars as we don't know what was in their hearts. The issue is in the authorship of the Bible, its consolidation, and its conveyance. We believe that mistakes were made or that the Romans purposefully changed the scripture at Nicea. Many Christian men denied the divinity of Jesus (meaning they denied the saying that Jesus is part of the creator of the universe) before Nicea. We believe that these people were on the truth.

We believe firmly that there is nothing comparable to God even remotely. Even a little. And that God is One, indivisible, eternal, uncreated, undying, and merciful.

I would rather stand before God on the day of resurrection and say "Oh my Maker, I denied that You became a man. It was nonsensical to me and reminiscent of paganism. You are far above creation and unlike anything that I can fathom. Forgive me."

As opposed to "Oh my Maker, I took another object of worship next to You. I took the portion of the English Bible that says Jesus was part of you literally. I worshipped Jesus as if he can aid me. As if he can answer my supplication. Oh God you have made it clear that you are the only One who answers supplication. The omnipotent. Forgive me."

God does not allow setting up partners with Him in worship, even if the object of worship is one of his noble servants and a prophet.

Jesus did not perform miracles except by the permission and ability of God.

body:
I'm not a catholic for anyone in the church, I'm a catholic for God. I have no interest in gossiping about what any other catholic is doing, what I'm asking you is to point out the faults in the doctrine I follow.

If you can't produce any questionable doctrine in my religion, then be polite enough to leave me well alone.
